values.Professor#4: Okay we're going to conduct a one-sample t-Test for the population mean.

So do we accept the null hypothesis or not?
Correct!, Since p < 0.05 we reject the null hypothesis.

So what would the conclusion be about the evidence obtained through the null hypothesis test?

values.2: The evidence suggests that there is a significant difference between the claim the teacher made about the average mark and the actual average mark.

values.Professor#1: We will go through a couple of steps to learn how to use techniques of the hypothesis test before, except for two or more populations.
values.Professor#2: firstly identify the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis?

values.3: The null hypothesis is: H0= Mu(physics) = Mu(math)

values.Professor#1: Correct!, The null hypothesis is: H0= Mu(physics) = Mu(math).
Incorrect! The null hypothesis is: H0= Mu(physics) = Mu(math).

values.Amanda#1: Therefore the alternative hypothesis is: H1=Mu(physics) doesn't equal Mu(Math)
values.Professor#1: Okay now there are conditions to a two sample test being valid, can you tell me what is required?

values.4: Our test is only valid if we can reasonably assume that both samples are drawn from normal distributions and that both samples are drawn from populations with equal spread.

values.Professor#1: Correct!, Our test is only valid if we can reasonably assume that both samples are drawn from normal distributions and that both samples are drawn from populations with equal spread.
Incorrect!, Our test is only valid if we can reasonably assume that both samples are drawn from normal distributions and that both samples are drawn from populations with equal spread.
Both subjects have different S-D. Try to evaluate the common standard deviation?
Correct!, S-D is 4.2536.
Incorrect!, S-D is 4.2536.
Now find the new t-score and degrees of freedom, then using the information given find the p value and determine whether we accept or not reject the null hypothesis?
Correct!, Using the t-score I found on a normal distribution tool I found the value to be p= 0.068.

values.2: There is evidence that suggest that there is not significant difference between the results of those in physics to those in mathematics.

$CEIdle|$POS0|Now that we have looked at some basic concepts in the previous levels, we can now begin to apply our knowledge of statistics at a higher level.
values.Professor#2: We will now be using data on the percentage yearly growth of GDP per capita for 184 countries.
values.Professor#3: And you may be wondering how the growth of GDP per capita might be related to poverty. That is a good question, one which I would like you to have a go at:
values.Eliza#2: Hmmm, how might growth of gdp per capita be related to poverty?

values.1: Poor countries would be expected to have a large gdp
values.2: Rich countries would be expected to have a large gdp
values.3: Poverty can be related to low yearly gdp per capita growth
values.4: Poverty can be related to high yearly gdp per capita growth

values.Professor#1: Correct! Rich countries would be expected to have a large gdp
values.Eliza#1: Poverty can be understood from many different perspectives.
values.Eliza#2: For a country with lower rates of poverty we would expect the yearly growth of gdp per capita to be increasing.

values.Professor#1: Incorrect! Rich countries would be expected to have a large gdp
In the data set above, we do not know the true value for the mean of the yearly gdp growth because not every country is included.
values.Professor#2: But we are given the sample mean and sample standard deviation.
values.Professor#3: Suppose we wish to conduct a test about the nature of the population mean of the yearly gdp per capita growth.
values.Professor#4: What type of distribution would be best?

values.2: Normal distribution with mean 1 and standard deviation

values.Professor#1: Correct!, T distribution, also known as the student’s t distribution.
values.Professor#2: An interesting property of the t distribution is that as the sample size gets larger the t distribution will tend to the standard normal distribution.
values.Professor#3: (which is the normal distribution with mean 0 and variance 1)

values.Professor#1: Correct!, T distribution, also known as the student’s t distribution.
values.Professor#2: An interesting property of the t distribution is that as the sample size gets larger the t distribution will tend to the standard normal distribution.
values.Professor#3: (which is the normal distribution with mean 0 and variance 1)

values.Professor#1: For now we will conduct a hypothesis test on only the 2019 data set.
values.Professor#2: Suppose we wish to test the hypothesis that true value for the yearly gdp per capita is not 3%.
values.Professor#3: What would be the appropriate test? Where M is the population mean.

values.1: H0: M is  more than 3; H1: M is equal to 3
values.2: H0: M is less than 3; H1: M is more than  3
values.3: H0: M is not equal to 3; H1: M is not equal to 3
values.4: H0: M is 3; H1: M is not equal to 3

values.Professor#1: Correct!, H0: M is 3; H1: M is not equal to 3
values.Professor#2: H1 is the hypothesis that we are interested in proving.
values.Professor#3: If the test does not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that this is the case, then we retain the null hypothesis H0.

values.Professor#1: Incorrect!, H0: M is 3; H1: M is not equal to 3
values.Professor#2: H1 is the hypothesis that we are interested in proving.
values.Professor#3: If the test does not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that this is the case, then we retain the null hypothesis H0.

values.Eliza#1: What would we say if let’s say, we do have enough evidence to accept the alternative?
values.Professor#1: Good question. We would say that there is insufficient evidence and reject the null hypothesis H0.
values.Professor#2: Now before we move on we need to know about Type 1 and Type 2 errors. What is the definition of a Type 1 error in relation to the hypothesis test?

values.1: When you accept a false null hypothesis
values.2: When you reject a false null hypothesis
values.3: When you reject a true null hypothesis

values.Professor#1: Correct!, Type 1 error is when you reject a true null hypothesis
Incorrect!, Type 1 error is when you reject a true null hypothesis
Now what is a type 2 error?

values.1: When you retain a true null hypothesis
values.2: When you prove a false null hypothesis
values.3: When you retain a false null hypothesis

values.Professor#1: Correct!, Type 2 error is when you retain a false null hypothesis
Incorrect!, Type 2 error is when you retain a false null hypothesis

values.Eliza#1: How are these related to the Hypothesis test?
values.Professor#1: Good question, type 1 and 2 errors are always present in every single hypothesis test
values.Professor#2: That is also why we never say we accept the null hypothesis or that we accept the alternative hypothesis.
values.Professor#3: We say retain, which is the keyword here. Because we cannot prove it is absolutely true.
values.Professor#4: If the chances of one error goes up then the other would decrease and vice versa.
values.Eliza#2: Is there any way we can minimise the errors?
values.Professor#5: We can choose which error we want to minimise.
values.Professor#6: The type 1 error is the probability of getting a false positive, whereas the type 2 error is the probability of getting a false negative.
values.Professor#7: We can alter the probability by using a value called the significance level.
values.Professor#8: So if the significance level is 5% then the confidence level of the test would be 95%.
values.Professor#9: We typically select 5% as the significance level and only change it in specific circumstances.
values.Professor#10: Generally if we increase the significance level then this would increase the likelihood of a Type 1 error and reduce the likelihood of a Type 2 error.
values.Professor#11: Both errors are inversely related like this.
values.Professor#12: So we will conduct our test at the 95% confidence level with the hypothesis test above, what will be the test statistic?

values.1: (sample mean-mean in null hypothesis)/(sample standard deviation/sqrt(sample size))

values.Professor#1: Correct, (sample mean-mean in null hypothesis)/(sample standard deviation/sqrt(sample size))
Incorrect, (sample mean-mean in null hypothesis)/(sample standard deviation/sqrt(sample size))
Now compute the value of the test statistic under the null hypothesis and determine the distribution of the test statistic
values.Professor#2: The sample mean is 2.950694444, and the sample standard deviation is 1.806380585, the sample size is 184.
The distribution for this will be the t distribution with 183 (=184-1) degrees of freedom. Remember you have to take away 1 from the degrees of freedom.
The distribution for this will be the t distribution with 183 (=184-1) degrees of freedom. Remember you have to take away 1 from the degrees of freedom.

values.Professor#1: Now that we have the test statistic, we can compute the p-value, but there is one problem.
values.Professor#2: If we use the standard tables for the t-distribution, they don’t go up to 183, so what should we do?

values.Professor#1: Correct, Use a different distribution.
values.Professor#2: Use the z-tables as n gets larger the t-distribution will approximate to the standard normal distribution.

values.Professor#1: Incorrect, Use a different distribution.
values.Professor#2: Use the z-tables as n gets larger the t-distribution will approximate to the standard normal distribution.

values.Professor#1: Find the p-value:

values.1: P-value = P(|Z|>test statistic) = 2 x P(Z<test statistic) = 2 x 0.3557 = 0.7114.

values.Professor#1: Correct, P-value = P(|Z|>test statistic) = 2 x P(Z<test statistic) = 2 x 0.3557 = 0.7114.
Incorrect, P-value = P(|Z|>test statistic) = 2 x P(Z<test statistic) = 2 x 0.3557 = 0.7114.
What would be an acceptable conclusion to the test?
We retain the null hypothesis as the p-value exceeds the significance level of 5%.
values.Professor#2: So there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the true value for yearly gdp per capita is different from 3%.

values.Professor#1: We retain the null hypothesis as the p-value exceeds the significance level of 5%.
values.Professor#2: So there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the true value for yearly gdp per capita is different from 3%.

values.Rebecca#1: Oh christ! Where am I? What's going on? This room is so white it's actually hurting my eyes.
values.Professor#1: Welcome to learning about the Health and Wellbeing UNSDG goal.
values.Professor#2: You are currently playing through the eyes of Rebecca Sutherland.
values.Professor#3: She is currently a statistician who works closely with the United Nations…
values.Professor#4: …to develop solutions to the specific Sustainable Development United Nations Goal of Health.
values.Professor#5: It MEANS, you are currently in possession of a memoram of someone quite knowledgeable and…
values.Professor#6: …should be able to assist you through most of the questions and statistics I will present to you.
values.Professor#7: Now if you don't mind, I-
values.Narrator#1: *Within Rebecca's body, Player runs down the hallway and turns into the first room they see, and shuts the door behind them*
values.Rebecca#3: Hah. Jokes on you. If I am an employee of the UN, that means I have access to all these doors and you don't.
values.Rebecca#4: Before that old sod tries to get through that door and ask me stupid questions again, let me think of a way to bust myself-
values.Professor#8: The fastest way you can “bust” yourself out of here, is to cooperate with me, you little rascal.
values.Narrator#2: *Player's turns around and see the Professor standing right in front of them, with the door still locked behind them*
values.Rebecca#5: WHAT! How did you manage to sneak behind me with…
values.Professor#9: Let me remind you that you are currently within a memoram.
values.Professor#10: Which is a virtual reality where we allow certain users to play through the memory of another person.
values.Professor#11: So you can't really just get away from me, as I am part of the system itself.
values.Professor#12: Were you really that naive to think that you can scram away when you are still within our system?
values.Professor#13: We brought you here for a reason, and we won't be letting you go until you learn what you have to learn.
values.Rebecca#6: Oh man. You are so irritating.
values.Professor#14: The feelings are mutual on this one.
values.Professor#15: Now! Onto our first question. What do you think a key indicator of good health in a country is?

values.1: Although there are many indicators at our disposal, Life expectancy is very reliable.

values.Rebecca#1: According to whatever is inside her head, life expectancy is the most reliable indicator for that?

values.Professor#1: That's so wrong!
According to whatever is inside her head, life expectancy is the most reliable indicator for that?
values.Professor#2: Then tell me, what do you think plays a big role in living a long life in Australia?

values.3: Demand and need for health and welfare services and health system costs

values.Rebecca#1: I would've much preferred the answers to not be as long as they are but what can I expect from a terrible system.
values.Professor#1: Ah yes. Save the smart-mouthing for answering my questions, yeah?
values.Rebecca#2: Fine. But answer me this, does the wealth of an individual necessarily determine how long they will live for?

values.Professor#1: That's wrong.
Well, let me answer that question with another question.
values.Professor#2: I have already provided you with the necessary resource, the Australian health reports,...
values.Professor#3: …observe the correlation between socioeconomics and health and tell me what you think?
values.Professor#4: And the data are recorded for those between the ages of 65-69, why do you think that it?

values.1: Those living in higher socioeconomic areas on average live longer lives.
values.2: Those living in higher socioeconomic areas on average live shorter lives.

values.Rebecca#1: To be fair, that's pretty self-explanatory.
values.Rebecca#2: People with a higher socioeconomic background have more access to healthcare facilities and systems than others.

values.Professor#1: Wrong.

values.Rebecca#1: But let me quickly ask, and stop changing my questions into your questions.
values.Rebecca#2: What factors do you think cause the impact of such a difference in life expectancy for socio economic groups?
values.Professor#1: Alright. For this I will partially answer it for you.
values.Professor#2: People of different incomes imply that they have different lifestyles, which means they all have different issues.
values.Professor#3: For example, allow me to present you the data sets on the link I gave you.
values.Professor#4: Now tell me the total disease burden for selected diseases, by socioeconomic area, 2015?
values.Rebecca#3: Looks like coronary disease is the highest impacting disease on Australians.
values.Professor#5: Exactly. Therefore as you can see, issues around health and wealth…
values.Professor#6: …play a big part in not just life expectancy but also the quality of life in terms of health.
values.Rebecca#4: Okay I can understand that. But another quick question..
values.Professor#7: You are quite curious now, aren't you?
values.Rebecca#5: Let me finish my sentence, you old sod.
values.Rebecca#6: I wonder if being educated is a good way to prevent people from experiencing health issues that could have been easily avoided.
values.Professor#8: That is an extremely good question and I'm so glad you mentioned that,…
values.Professor#9: because I think it's important for you to tell me which age group,...
values.Professor#10: …education level and gender are most vulnerable to cardiovascular disease?
values.Professor#11: I will assist you by giving you these graphs as references.

values.1: Men aged 30-48 years with no post secondary and year 11
values.2: Men aged 65-84 years with no post secondary and year 12

values.Professor#1: Nicely done.
Well that's wrong.

values.Rebecca#1: Apparently this person that I am currently controlling is supposed to ask this question at some point.
values.Rebecca#2: And since you are so helpful right now. Let me just relay that question for her right now.
values.Rebecca#3: There was apparently a  project I did a long time ago but I still don't know what I should have done.
values.Rebecca#4: I had to choose from two datasets, and I did not know which one to choose.
values.Professor#1: Okay. I have an idea what you might be talking about.
values.Professor#2: But describe to me about these datasets that Rebecca apparently knows of.
values.Rebecca#6: The first dataset was collected from anonymous questionnaires and…
values.Rebecca#7: …we surveyed people of many different ages, addresses, and backgrounds.
values.Rebecca#8: While the second dataset was collected from a specific group of people…
values.Rebecca#9: …that were pretty much the same age and background with very little variation.
values.Professor#10: Interesting. And can you tell me about the aim of the project that you were doing?
values.Rebecca#10: We were testing the hypothesis that changes in temperature are related to changes in height throughout the day.
values.Professor#11: That's so interesting! And what do you think we should do here?
values.Rebecca#11: Am I not the one asking you the question?!
values.Professor#12: Yes, and I am asking you what's the answer?

values.Rebecca#1: Thank you so much Professor. You are so absolutely helpful in these situations.
values.Rebecca#2: I could have never guessed you would answer my question with another question again.
values.Professor#1: Exactly. Very good Rebecca. You are quickly learning. I am so glad to be of help.
Wrong.

values.Rebecca#1: Well, all of these questions got me thinking. And by me, I mean Rebecca.
values.Rebecca#2: Because why not, she seems like a person who has a lot of questions on. her. MIND.
values.Rebecca#3: If we consider a hypothetical situation where the ages of all subjects in a dataset are the same, where would we use that dataset?
values.Professor#1: Well, that's a pretty good question.
values.Professor#2: I will give you a bunch of answers and you can choose for yourself which one is the right one?

values.1: A data set relevant to that age would be required
values.2: A data set relevant to that species should be required

values.Professor#1: That's correct.
That's incorrect

values.Rebecca#1: Well. That's all her questions answered. She also has a project that she wants to talk about?
values.Rebecca#2: Are you serious? What is this, am I getting sponsored for this. Jesus.
values.Rebecca#3: “My project is focused on Malaria research. I'll give some information about Malaria in countries where it is found:
values.Rebecca#4: Malaria is a disease transmitted by a parasite through the bites of infected mosquitos.
values.Rebecca#5: Malaria is very rare in countries like Australia but is more prevalent in tropical countries in South America and Africa.
values.Rebecca#6: Each year 290 million people are infected with Malaria worldwide and over 400,000 people die from this disease.
values.Rebecca#7: Part of my research is based on this.
values.Professor#1: Oh well. You are running through her memoram.
values.Professor#2: You have no choice but to always go through whatever predetermined sequence that she had gone through before.
values.Professor#3: Alright. Congratulations on completing your first level of this goal. Are you ready to move on to the second level?

values.Professor#1: Let's move on.
Well, you can't stay anyways.
